SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. However, his diet has been off due to recent home renovations, leading to eating out more frequently and consuming less healthy food options.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Endorses slight cramps that resolve within an hour.
• Respiratory: Slight cough. Endorses shortness of breath during exertion.
• Gastrointestinal: Occasional bloating. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any significant weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and stumbled, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain upon flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment appears normal.

IMPRESSION

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to take every 6 hours with food for two weeks as needed for pain.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He is taking his medication for hypertension but acknowledges that his blood pressure readings have been a bit high.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes (resolved).

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoiding strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been compliant with medication but admits to a recent poor diet. His hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings have been running high, and his blood pressure is elevated in the office today.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been monitoring his knee and managing his symptoms. No further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been managing his hypertension with Norvasc, though he admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. The patient experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs, particularly in humid conditions. He also reports nasal congestion due to pollen.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Nasal congestion.
• Cardiovascular: Chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Depression managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill Prozac prescription.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly, and breathing function is fine.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on Norvasc.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication and monitor blood pressure.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient reports being anemic since the age of 13. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, and increased anxiety and depression. She has a history of heavy periods but had a hysterectomy in 1996. The patient has been taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: once or twice a year.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
2. Hematologist referral: Send a referral to Dr. Flores for further evaluation and management of anemia.
3. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.
4. Follow up with the clinic for any questions or worsening symptoms.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy. Schedule an appointment with Dr. Flores, the hematologist. Follow bowel prep instructions for the procedures. Call the clinic with any additional concerns or questions.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH, and an MRI revealing a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

The patient describes his headaches as a dull, nagging ache located behind his eyes, with a gradual onset and worsening severity over the past three months. The headaches tend to be worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. No other associated symptoms were reported.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

Family
Unknown, patient was adopted.

Social
Computer programmer, married for 25 years, non-smoker, non-drinker, no recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. Since the initial episode, the patient reports that her symptoms have resolved.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal.

Surgical
Cholecystectomy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol: Not mentioned.
Illicit drug use: Not mentioned.
Tobacco: Not mentioned.
Family: Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Not mentioned.

ALLERGIES

Not mentioned.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain, abnormal bowel movements.
Positive for chest pain, difficulty swallowing (resolved since October 2020).

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved since October 2020, and she has not experienced any additional episodes. The patient reported a stressful job transition around the time of the initial episode, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate the esophagus and stomach. However, the patient prefers to hold off on the procedure and monitor her symptoms.
2. The patient will self-monitor her symptoms and call the office if any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms occur.
3. If needed, the patient will follow up for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome evaluation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies associated with the syndrome, prompting the visit for a kidney evaluation.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Feeding difficulties.
Reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with possible congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
3. If the ultrasound is abnormal, determine next steps and schedule a follow-up appointment at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow up as needed based on the findings. Call the clinic with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not mentioned.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation, pain on flexion, extension, radial and ulnar deviation, and difficulty making a tight fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss the possibility of her going on vacation.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend physical therapy sessions. If there are any concerns or worsening of symptoms, the patient should contact the office immediately.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Pain with flexion and extension of the right knee. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee. Edema around the knee and effusion present.
- Right knee: No pain with movement on the lateral aspect of the knee.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing pain and swelling in the right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily. Advise the patient to elevate and stay off the leg for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of lisinopril. Blood pressure was 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg. Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help improve diet and potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects that it might be related to that. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The onset of her pain is occasional, occurring less than once a day, and is described as a sudden feeling of the knee giving out. The patient reports that the pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap. She denies any history of injury, pop sensation, or prolonged pain. The patient mentions that the knee issue does not significantly interfere with her daily activities, but she is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to the knee instability.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled.
3. Diabetes mellitus, slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to Metformin dosage. Encourage the patient to continue monitoring blood sugars and maintain a healthy diet.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports minimal cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting, no difficulty swallowing.
Psychiatric: Mentally and emotionally stable with good support system.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess tumor shrinkage and potential for surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has mild radiation pneumonitis causing cough and potential shortness of breath.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has inflammation in the esophagus due to radiation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and improve ability to eat and drink.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds during the winter months that tend to linger. No recent history of abdominal infections or diarrhea. Patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop.

TRAVEL HISTORY

Recent international travel to Zambia.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezing, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY DATA

Low IgA level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not seem to have frequent infections that would warrant concern.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibodies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Informed patient about IgA deficiency and advised to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in the abdominal tract. Instructed patient to inform healthcare providers of IgA deficiency if needing blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Continue management with metformin and lifestyle modifications.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is located on the inside of his elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. He has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which may have contributed to the pain. The patient rates the pain as a 6/10 and states that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain with radiation into the forearm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist. No pain with supination.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony misalignment.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath.
Genitourinary: Denies urinary incontinence.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting his sodium intake. He could try keeping a food diary, as previously discussed, to log his diet and associated blood pressure readings. I also advised him to monitor his weight daily and contact me if he gains 3 pounds in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding his diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: He can continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in waves. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father. He has taken Tylenol for the pain with minimal relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Patient may continue to take Tylenol as needed.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to assess progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient has noticed a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the wound turning black around the edges. He has also experienced cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with 2-3 days left in the course. He reports a fever of 99.7 and chills before starting antibiotics. The patient's blood sugars have been running high, with recent readings in the 300-400 range.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike with new diabetic shoes and inserts.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills before starting antibiotics.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking around the house.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No reported issues.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot exam: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent poor blood sugar control
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed with the patient the need for further evaluation and treatment of his non-healing right foot ulcer. I will order a test to check blood supply for the wound and perform a debridement in the office today. A culture will be taken, and antibiotic therapy may be adjusted based on the results. The patient will continue his current antibiotic course and follow up in 7 days. I have advised the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to address his recent poor blood sugar control and maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports a tick bite on the right knee, which occurred over a week ago. Patient experiences burning sensation and discomfort in the area. No fever or chills reported. Patient has a history of tick bites but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain since tick bite.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Normal
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee. Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to evaluate long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
